analysis.raw_analysis:
1) TRANSFORMATION: Height scaled 6->9 (×1.5); width unchanged. Color 1 → 2, 0 stays 0.

2) PATTERN: Take the input, map 1→2, and extend the vertical polyline by appending a 3‑row block that continues the existing 3‑row motif, yielding 9 rows (the colored snake is repeated/extended).

3) KEY CHANGES:
- Ex1: 1→2; append rows 0–2 (recolored).
- Ex2: 1→2; append rows 2–4 (recolored).
- Ex3: 1→2; append rows 0–2 (recolored).

=== INPUT-INPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Differences: horizontal protrusions and exact row pattern vary (which rows have 1s).
- Same: all inputs are 6x3, use colors 0 and 1, and contain a single connected vertical polyline of 1s.

=== OUTPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Exactly same: all outputs are 9x3, palette {0,2}, zeros remain 0, ones become 2, top 6 rows = input with 1->2.

=== INPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Transformations that hold for ALL examples:
  1) Color map: 1 -> 2; 0 unchanged.
  2) Height: 6 -> 9 by appending a 3-row block that continues/extends the vertical polyline (so the output’s last three rows extend the input stroke).

Reference objects: the single connected vertical shape of 1s (with its left/right horizontal protrusions). Its column positions and local row patterns stay fixed and guide where to extend.

Grid pattern: map 1->2, 0 stays 0, keep width. Scale height by 1.5 by vertically tiling/repeating the object's row-sequence until new height reached (append rows from the object's pattern).

Objects: the main connected region of 1s is the only important object; preserve its horizontal protrusions and repeat its row pattern to extend vertically.

=== GENERAL RULE ===
1. Step 1: IF the input grid has height = 6 and width = 3 THEN create an output grid of height = 9 and width = 3 initialized with color 0 in every cell.  
2. Step 2: IF a cell in the input grid (row r, column c) has color 1 THEN set the cell at the same coordinates (row r, column c) in the output grid to color 2.  
3. Step 3: IF a cell in the input grid (row r, column c) has color 0 THEN set the cell at the same coordinates (row r, column c) in the output grid to color 0 (leave unchanged).  
4. Step 4: IF the input contains exactly one connected object made of color 1 (a single vertical polyline) THEN locate a contiguous 3-row segment of that object that represents one full local motif of the polyline’s horizontal-protrusion pattern (i.e., three consecutive input rows that together show the left/center/right protrusion arrangement that recurs along the snake).  
5. Step 5: IF the 3-row motif from Step 4 is identified THEN copy that 3-row block (preserving each column position) and place it into the output grid as rows 6,7,8 (directly below the original rows 0–5), mapping color 1 -> color 2 when copying.  
6. Step 6: IF more than one 3-row motif candidate exists THEN choose the candidate whose top row has a 1 in the center column aligned vertically with the object’s bottommost 1 so that the appended block remains connected to the original object; then perform the copy in Step 5.  
7. Step 7: IF any cell in the output grid was not set by Steps 2–6 THEN leave that cell as color 0.

general_steps.instruction: Step 1: TRANSFORM - Step 1: IF the input grid has height = 6 and width = 3 THEN create an output grid of height = 9 and width = 3 initialized with color 0 in every cell.
Step 2: TRANSFORM - Step 2: IF a cell in the input grid (row r, column c) has color 1 THEN set the cell at the same coordinates (row r, column c) in the output grid to color 2.
Step 3: OBSERVE - Step 3: IF a cell in the input grid (row r, column c) has color 0 THEN set the cell at the same coordinates (row r, column c) in the output grid to color 0 (leave unchanged).

Step 4: TRANSFORM - Step 4: IF the input contains exactly one connected object made of color 1 (a single vertical polyline) THEN locate a contiguous 3-row segment of that object that represents one full local motif of the polyline’s horizontal-protrusion pattern (i.e., three consecutive input rows that together show the left/center/right protrusion arrangement that recurs along the snake).

Step 5: TRANSFORM - Step 5: IF the 3-row motif from Step 4 is identified THEN copy that 3-row block (preserving each column position) and place it into the output grid as rows 6,7,8 (directly below the original rows 0–5), mapping color 1 -> color 2 when copying.

Step 6: TRANSFORM - Step 6: IF more than one 3-row motif candidate exists THEN choose the candidate whose top row has a 1 in the center column aligned vertically with the object’s bottommost 1 so that the appended block remains connected to the original object; then perform the copy in Step 5.
Step 7: TRANSFORM - Step 7: IF any cell in the output grid was not set by Steps 2–6 THEN leave that cell as color 0.
